title: Python
text: Python is the programming language I have used the most, and will be my go-to for smaller research projects and quick turn-arounds.

title: Vue3
text: Vue3 is my preferred JS frontend framework (and what this website is written in). Almost all the web dev work I have done is using Vue3.

title: Ansible
text: I have used Ansible for standing up fairly simplistic VMs for dev environments. I really like Ansible but rarely have the need to write a playbook.

title: Docker
text: I tend to Dockerize almost every app I write. I am very proficient with docker-compose as well, and using multiple containers across a network.

title: Matlab
text: I have used Matlab extensively in years past (and was a TA for an intro Matlab course) but since college I have not needed to use it.

title: Java
text: Java was the first language I learned and I used to use it for backends with Spring and Thymeleaf. I haven't written any Java recently.

title: TypeScript
text: In my opinion, JavaScript is irrelevant in modern development so long as TypeScript exists. I prefer to only use TypeScript whenever possible.

title: FastAPI
text: I prefer FastAPI over Flask when standing up Python web backends. It is much more performant, and far more convenient when it comes to dependency injection.

title: Flask
text: While I have used Flask quite a bit, I prefer FastAPI. Flask requires so many 3rd party helper libraries that I am not familiar with all of them.

title: Rust
text: Rust is a language I am actively learning. It's syntax and safety features are beautiful, and if Rust is the future I want to be a part of it.

title: React
text: I have used React quite a bit in the past, but abandoned it once I learned Vue. I much prefer Vue, but am flexible to the desires of any project.

title: SQLAlchemy
text: I have used SQLAlchemy (and Alembic) extensively in my projects. I am constantly learning with it, which is why I love it.

title: React Native
text: When I switched from Android to iOS and lost all my apps, I decided to learn React Native. I wish I had more time for it.

title: C#
text: I actually prefer C# to Java, and wish I had the opportunity to do more .NET development in general because of it.

title: C
text: It's been a long time since I have seen a seg fault, but I came the closest to an all nighter in my life writing C.

title: Express
text: I have used Express for a few projects, but I prefer FastAPI for most development. I am comfortable with Express, but not an expert.

title: Sequelize
text: I have used Sequelize with Express and it is my preferred ORM for NodeJS. I especially like the migration support and that they are adding more and more TypeScript support.

title: AWS
text: AWS is something I have used extensively in my current role. I have spun up services on ECS and EKS and am very comfortable with Cognito and Amplify.

title: Kubernetes
text: Kubernetes is something I had to learn for my current role. I am now quite familiar with Helm, and can navigate a cluster with kubectl efficiently.

title: PostgreSQL
text: Postgres is my preferred SQL database, mainly because of the helper functions it has that can be used with arrays. The JSON support can also be very useful.

title: MySQL/MariaDB
text: Honestly the only reason I have ever used MySQL or MariaDB was so I could use MySQL Workbench. I have found DBeaver also has similar ERD support for Postgres so I have mainly switched to that.

title: Elasticsearch
text: I have mainly used Elasticsearch when working with data scientists to add search capabilities for big data in backend systems.

title: MongoDB
text: Mongo is my preferred NoSQL database. I have used it for a few projects and have found it to be very easy to use and integrate with Python.

title: d3.js
text: I have used d3.js to make several data visualizations, but I am not an expert. It is something I am currently expanding on in my role.

title: ROS
text: Much of the software I write in my current role runs in ROS or micro-ROS and leverages its DDS capabilities to handle communication between Docker containers.

title: Unraid
text: I have used Unraid for my personal server for years (it's serving this website). I also run Home Assistant, Pi-hole and Plex, as well as many other things.
